child.pub-comments: “We may apply the term Proto-Fijian to the end-point in the development of the original dialect continuum, immediately before its divergence into Eastern and Western divisions. In fact, the divergence was probably gradual, with the Eastern and Western speech communities continuing to speak mutually intelligible languages, and only partly independent in their evolution, for many centuries after the first sharp break developed between the western Viti Levu speech forms and those of the east. […] The breakup of Proto-Fijian was just the breakup of one large dialect chain into two smaller dialect chains” (Pawley and Sayaba 1971:434).

“The Western subgroup is geographically more compact, the level of mutual intelligibility between all its member communalects has remained high, and grammatically and phonologically it is rather more homogeneous than Eastern Fijian. However, the quite considerable grammatical and phonological differences which distinguish the most widely separated Western dialects—those of Ba province on the one hand, and Nadrogā and Serua on the other—suggest that Western Fijian has for some time ceased to evolve grammatically and phonologically as a unity” (Pawley and Sayaba 1971:432). “With one exception, every known communalect on or west of the Nadrau Plateau can be assigned, on genetic and typological grounds, to Western Fijian” (Pawley and Sayaba 1971:408-409).

child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K & Timoci Sayaba. 1971. Fijian Dialect Divisions: Eastern and Western Fijian, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, No. 4 edn., vol. 80, 405-436. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.pub-comments: “Our most extensive materials are on the dialect spoken on Waya Island in the Yasawas” (Pawley and Sayaba 1971:407).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K & Timoci Sayaba. 1971. Fijian Dialect Divisions: Eastern and Western Fijian, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, No. 4 edn., vol. 80, 405-436. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.
child.geography: spoken on Waya Island in the Yasawa Island group

child.pub-comments: “The Eastern subgroup as a whole probably ceased to be an evolutionary unity—to undergo systematic changes which spread to all members of the subgroup—at least several centuries ago” (Pawley and Sayaba 1971:432). “ With a few exceptions, every known Viti Levu communalect to the east can be assigned to Eastern Fijian” (Pawley and Sayaba 1971:409).
“Every well described communalect can be unambiguously assigned to one subgroup or the other. This includes those Ra and Namosi communalects for which we have data” (Pawley and Sayaba 1971:410).

child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K & Timoci Sayaba. 1971. Fijian Dialect Divisions: Eastern and Western Fijian, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, No. 4 edn., vol. 80, 405-436. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.pub-comments: “Informants at Lewā told us that Rabula was the most western of the Eastern speaking villages in the coastal region of Ra Province” (Pawley and Sayaba 1971:408, fn 14).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K & Timoci Sayaba. 1971. Fijian Dialect Divisions: Eastern and Western Fijian, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, No. 4 edn., vol. 80, 405-436. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

Pawley, Andrew K & Timoci Sayaba. 1971. Fijian Dialect Divisions: Eastern and Western Fijian, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, No. 4 edn., vol. 80, 405-436. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.pub-comments: “... the village of Nadrau, referred to earlier, is often spoken of as having a mixed dialect. However, the Nadrau communalect is clearly a member of the Eastern subgroup. In particular, it closely resembles the group of communalects centred around the villages of Nasoqo and Nasiriti along the Nasoqo River, a tributary of the Wainimala, on the eastern side of the Nadrau Plateau” (Pawley and Sayaba 1971:410).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K & Timoci Sayaba. 1971. Fijian Dialect Divisions: Eastern and Western Fijian, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, No. 4 edn., vol. 80, 405-436. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.pub-comments: “The easternmost members of the Fiji group, the Lau Islands, lie only 180 miles west of Vava'u in the Tongan archipelago” (Pawley and Sayaba 1971:416, fn 46).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K & Timoci Sayaba. 1971. Fijian Dialect Divisions: Eastern and Western Fijian, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, No. 4 edn., vol. 80, 405-436. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.pub-comments: “...the communalects spoken in north-east Vanua Levu are well differentiated from those of south-west of Vanua Levu, but are connected by dialects of transitional form. The whole of Vanua Levu is a single dialect chain. […] It is part of a continuum which embraces most, possibly all, of eastern Fiji” (Pawley and Sayaba 1971:408).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K & Timoci Sayaba. 1971. Fijian Dialect Divisions: Eastern and Western Fijian, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, No. 4 edn., vol. 80, 405-436. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.pub-comments: “But after one of the eastern dialects – Bauan – was established as the standard literary language and the main lingua franca of Fijians, almost a century passed before systematic study of the non-standard dialects was resumed” (Pawley and Sayaba 1971:405-06).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K & Timoci Sayaba. 1971. Fijian Dialect Divisions: Eastern and Western Fijian, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, No. 4 edn., vol. 80, 405-436. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.
